data.title: Highlights From The Trump Administration's East Asia Deals
data.description:
In the week beginning on October 24, 2025, President Trump and his administration met with East Asian leaders. The President stopped first in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, followed by Japan and South Korea. Last, but not least, and most importantly, he met with Chinese President Xi on Thursday, Oct. 30.

What did the meeting with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (“ASEAN”) accomplish?

Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand

The White House segmented the President’s deals into three groups: peace deals, trade deals, and critical minerals deals. The peace deal might have minimal interest to readers, since defense firms like Lockheed Martin Corporation (LMT), The Boeing Company (BA), or RTX Corporation (RTX). Product sales for defense contractors are bigger in other markets and countries. For example, RTX stock jumped by 6.11% in the last month to continue its yearlong uptrend.

RTX posted resilient strength in commercial aerospace, thanks to passenger air travel resiliency. In addition, Pratt Canada serviced nearly 70,000 engines. RTX’s backlog grew by 13% Y/Y to $251 billion. Its book-to-bill in Q3 was 1.63. Collins and Pratt’s customers included NASA, General Electric Company (GE), SpaceX, and Textron Inc. (TXT).

Malaysia and Cambodia eliminated tariffs on U.S. exports. While that expands market access for U.S. products, the White House posted that “non-tariff barriers will be addressed.”

Malaysia (EWM) imported $299.5 billion in 2024. The U.S. accounted for $27.60 billion. China accounted for 24%, according to Trading Economics:

Cambodia imported $28.71 billion. Again, China was its biggest source of imports at 48%, compared to $264.17 million from the U.S.

Vietnam (VNM) Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and President Trump announced a joint statement on a U.S.-Vietnam Framework for an Agreement on Reciprocal, Fair, and Balanced Trade. The deal is incomplete. A fact sheet issued that day stated that the two countries would continue to negotiate in the coming weeks to finalize the deal.

Vietnam exports will face a 20% tariff. Any transshipment from third countries faces a 40% duty. Still, Vietnam will improve market access by resolving constraints that U.S. exports face. For example, it would recognize vehicles that meet U.S. safety and emission standards. Vietnam would simplify regulatory approvals for U.S. pharmaceutical products.

Vietnam Airlines signed a deal to buy 50 Boeing aircraft worth $8 billion.

To get an idea of Vietnam’s market size, look at the $379 billion imports in 2024. This grew by 7.2% Y/Y. China and Vietnam reached $144.3 billion worth of trade in 2024-25. The U.S. remained a key trade partner, where imports totaled $14.3 billion. It supplied Vietnam, which focused on agriculture, machinery, technology, and rubber.

Thailand agreed to eliminate tariffs on 99% of goods. Thailand (THD) will buy U.S. agricultural, energy products and aircraft. This has a value of over $20 billion.

Deal With Japan

Japan (EWJ) and the U.S. signed an agreement where the U.S. would tax goods imported from Japan at 15%. Japan agreed to create a $550 billion fund of investments in the U.S. Japanese firms expressed interest in launching projects in the U.S. worth around $400 billion in total. They want to invest in energy, which AI infrastructure requires to run. Still, the Japan Times reported that the deal did not finalize any of the projects.

Honda Motor Co., Ltd. (HMC), Toyota Motor Corporation (TM), and Sony Group Corporation (SONY) are among the biggest firms to watch. Tariffs have an impact on their export volumes.

Above: Sony is the first in its industry rank, while Toyota scores a B or higher in all of its quant factor grades.

China Deal

The U.S. did not sign a trade deal when the two leaders met for less than two hours (as reported by CNN). This was a face-to-face talk in Busan, South Korea (EWY), which was their first meeting since 2019. Trump agreed to lower tariffs on Chinese exports to 47%, down from 57%. The U.S. will cut the tariff rates related to fentanyl precursor drugs by half, to 10%.

China agreed to pause (delay for one year), not cancel, export controls on rare earths. Similarly, Treasury Secretary Bessent confirmed that the U.S. would pause its new expansion of export controls. This freezes the 50% BIS (Bureau of Industry and Security) rule. The rule would have extended last year’s announced export-licensing requirements. That would have applied to firms that were majority-owned by parties on the entity list, military end-user list, or part of the specially designated nationals.

China agreed to buy 12 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans until January 2026. It will buy 25 million tons a year for the next three years. China bought 28.8 million tons on average in the last five September-to-August crop seasons. Soybean (SOYB) prices have jumped since October 10. SOYB stock is up by around 6.5% in the last month.

Bessent said that China approved the transfer agreement for TikTok. A Chinese spokesperson said, “The Chinese side will work with the U.S. side to properly address issues related to TikTok." Ahead of the news, Oracle Corporation (ORCL), considered a frontrunner in acquiring the short-form video site, underperformed. ORCL stock potentially peaked at around $340. The stock has spiked at lower highs since September and is down by 7.68% in the last week.

Trump said on Truth Social that China would buy U.S. oil and gas. Additionally, he announced a “very large-scale transaction (that) may take place” involving Alaska. Some liquefied natural gas stocks to explore further include Cheniere Energy, Inc. (LNG), Kinder Morgan, Inc. (KMI), and Energy Transfer LP (ET). ConocoPhillips (COP) is Alaska’s biggest oil producer. Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) has a stake in the Prudhoe Bay oil field, but Hilcorp replaced it as the operator in 2021.

Above: XOM stock has the highest sector rank. It has a 'Strong Buy' on Seeking Alpha's Quant Ratings.

Potential Economic Impact

Readers who craved for firm trade deals might be disappointed. The U.S. and China paused tariffs and restrictions, respectively, for one year. They will continue to play their long game using short-term agreements in principle. Investors will need to exercise caution in holding companies that struggled before tariffs. For example, Newell Brands Inc. (NWL) lost 32% despite indicating the impact of tariffs subsiding in 2026.

China is not faring well economically. Weaker exports, hurt by U.S. tariffs, resulted in factory activity falling to a six-month low. China’s (FXI) NBS Manufacturing PMI fell to 49.0%. Investors would not likely notice the weak data. FXI stock is up by 25% in the last year. The country’s technology stocks are up, too. Alibaba Group Holding Limited (BABA) gained 98.8% and Tencent Holdings Limited (OTCPK:TCEHY) is up by 51.8% YTD. Technology investors need not worry about the absence of discussing NVIDIA Corporation's (NVDA) Blackwell chip sales to China. The AI race to the top will continue between the U.S. and China.

Above: In the five-day period, shares of Tencent, Baidu, Inc. (BIDU), Alibaba, and JD.com, Inc. (JD) pulled back. Below: BIDU and JD shares offer compelling value.

Your Takeaway

Stock markets trade near their all-time highs. In the last week, earnings reports from the Magnificent Seven, along with the Federal Reserve’s 25 bps rate cut, influenced markets heavily. In the coming weeks, the U.S. will get a better idea of the impact of the deals with ASEAN nations, especially with China.

data.title: Lowe's: Price May Follow Earnings And Recover With Consumers, But Upside Could Be Capped
data.description:
Lowe's Companies, Inc. (NYSE:LOW) is an American retail company, specializing in home improvement, maintenance, and decorating products and services. This is one of a few market-leading companies with a significant presence, highlighting more than 1,700 stores.

LOW stock has declined by 9% over the past 12 months, mainly driven by weak US consumer demand due to an elevated interest-rate environment and slower demand for home improvements. I think a meaningful decrease in new home sales trends, experienced since about 2021, has also significantly contributed to its bearish performance. Although the chart below highlights that new home sales may resume, it may take time for this to translate into significant top and bottom-line growth.

This is why I think that Lowe's Companies is a Hold with a $266 price target over the next 12 months. This suggests roughly market-like returns, highlighting a 9% upside possibility without dividends. I believe the stock price may mirror bottom-line growth.

However, unless consumers significantly recover and real estate activity increases, I am not sure whether the company can substantially outperform the benchmark in the following year. It has several tailwinds tied to a dovish Fed and easing cycle, but policy might take time; therefore, I remain cautious and monitor the macroeconomic outlook.

FQ2 2026 Snapshot: Double-Beat Performance, Guiding For A Positive Shift

On August 20, the company delivered FQ2 2026 results. This was a double-beat quarter, implying a shift in resumed top-line growth and bottom-line increase. However, based on the neutral investors' reaction, it seems that the market had already anticipated a turnaround, as the stock remained flat with roughly a 0.60% drop over the following trading day.

Lowe's posted $23.96 billion in revenue, up by 1.58% on a year-over-year basis, breaking the streak of 9 consecutive top-line decline quarters. This arrived at about $9 million above what the market had anticipated. The bottom line came in at $4.33 in diluted EPS, indicating approximately 6% increase versus $4.10 in the same quarter last year, and $0.09 above the analysts' estimates, implying a 2% surprise.

Management highlighted that the comparable sales increased by 1.1%, which is uplifting, considering the company has been experiencing a multi-month top-line contraction. The retail company underscored that it achieved 33.8% gross margin and 14.5% operating margin.

The home renovation business represented a 3.6% increase in comparable sales for ticket sizes exceeding $500, which I believe is promising and supports a bullish future. This also correlates to an increase in new home sales in the US, implying that home renovation products are typically tied to a higher price tag. Moreover, it may indicate that consumer spending is improving, and that would be a positive tailwind for this retail industry.

On the upside, the company highlighted it has experienced positive comparable sales in 9 out of 15 regions it operates. This also supports a bullish narrative and may sustain a positive stock price momentum, underlining a roughly 7% increase over the past 6 months. I think this quarterly report underscored a promising shift in the company's performance. If the trend continues, I believe Lowe may rebound from these levels.

Lowe's is expected to deliver its FQ3 2026 results on November 19, before the market opens. The market is forecasting $20.88 billion in revenue, implying about a 3.5% growth on a year-over-year basis, and roughly $3.00 in diluted EPS, representing approximately a 3.7% increase over the past 12 months. I think the company appears to be well-positioned to achieve these results. Given its recent performance and uptick in new home sales, LOW may meet the market expectations. If that materializes, investor confidence may improve, followed by expectations of a recovering consumer.

Lowe's Appears To Be Fairly Priced, And I Argue That The Market Has Priced In The Consumer Recovery

The home renovation retailer currently trades at a forward P/E of about 20, which appears to be approximately 12% overvalued versus the sector median of around 18 earnings multiples. However, versus the average company in the S&P500 at roughly 24x, Lowe's trades at a 20% discount.

The chart above also suggests that the current valuation reflects the high end of the trading range, which supports my outlook that upside may be limited in the near term. The forward P/E has increased significantly from about the mid-14's back in December 2023 to the current levels, mainly driven by the bottoming phase in the real estate market, as that period reflected the weakest activity over the past years. This also may support my stance that consumer recovery may already be priced in.

On the forward PEG (non-GAAP) basis of 3.16, the company appears to be trading at a substantial premium to peers at 1.73. This implies more than an 80% premium, which adds an extra argument to my bearish stance. This also clouds a positive outlook.

The forward EV/Sales and Price/Sales ratios of 2.01 and 1.61, respectively, justify my thesis supporting a slightly bearish outlook, and that the market may have already priced in the improvement of consumer spending. This presents 60% overvaluation at the midpoint versus the sector median of 1.35 and 0.97. This also shows that even though the home renovation company may post an acceleration in top-line growth, this does not necessarily result in stock price appreciation.

Lowe's remains a heavily leveraged company, and that may cap the upside in the near term. The retail name has $39 billion in total obligations, which appears to be significant, and resulted in $355 million in interest expenses to service the debt. Although it has $5.26 billion in cash that partially offsets its obligations, it remains elevated and could weigh on the stock price further.

The company had achieved a roughly flat performance on both top and bottom lines over the past year. LOW experienced a 0.49% revenue decline and 0.93% EPS growth over the past 12 months. This may suggest that the current valuation appears slightly too high. However, I think investors have priced in the consumer recovery, which resulted in a premium multiple. Nevertheless, this suggests that if the company experiences weaker-than-anticipated results, the stock price could correct from these levels.

The retail company has been operating at a roughly market-like gross profit margin (TTM) of about 34%, which justifies a fair valuation. This implies about a 13% discount to peers in the consumer discretionary segment, but I think that with consumer recovery, the company may be able to enhance profitability metrics. However, this is an area to monitor for investors, as higher margins could result in premium multiples.

On the other hand, the net income margin (TTM) of 8.20% reflects about 2x outperformance versus peers of 4.31%, and that supports a bullish narrative for the company. This also highlights that LOW remains a highly profitable business, which may fuel the bottom-line growth in the following years. This also supports my thesis that the stock price may follow EPS expansion.

Wall Street estimates a $12.32 in diluted EPS for fiscal FY2026, up by 3% on a year-over-year basis, and $13.32 for fiscal FY2027, reflecting 8% increase versus the fiscal FY2026 estimate. I think Lowe's appears to be well-positioned to achieve these results. The company remains profitable, operating at market-like margins. If real estate activity continues to improve, and consumer spending rises, this may act as a substantial tailwind driving the bottom-line growth.

If we apply a roughly current earnings multiple of 20x to a fiscal FY2027 EPS estimate of $13.32, we arrive at my price target of $266. This would represent about 9% upside possibility, driven by bottom-line growth. However, given the macroeconomic uncertainties, I think the stock may mirror its EPS performance, yet I am not sure whether LOW can significantly outperform the benchmark without a significant revenue growth catalyst.

Main Risks And Concerns

There are risks and concerns tied to Lowe's that could meaningfully impact the stock price performance in the short term.

The home renovation company is highly dependent on the macroeconomic outlook. If inflation remains elevated or the job market weakens, this could result in slower-than-anticipated consumer spending and suppressed sentiment. This may also encourage the Fed to pause the easing cycle, which would establish an unfavorable environment for the company. This could stress its performance and result in continued underperformance.

Although new home sales experienced an uptick, and their growth appears to be resuming, it may not necessarily be the case. There is a possibility that, followed by macroeconomic uncertainties, new home sales may come in weaker-than-anticipated. This could pressure the stock price further.

Lowe's is exposed to tariffs, and that is a concern. This is another argument for suppressed margins, and if tariffs will remain a concern over the following years, the market may reprice the company at a lower multiple. Because of this, the company is also experiencing cost inflation, which supports my limited upside narrative.

Considering its 12-month top and bottom-line performance, LOW experiences stagnation. However, it also trades at only a 20% discount to the benchmark. This suggests that if the outlook remains cloudy, investors may not be willing to pay a higher premium for the company.

On the upside, if none of the above materializes, and tariff risks and concerns fade away, the company could continue trading at a premium, and there may even be room for multiple expansion. I believe that investors should monitor whether an uptick in new home sales was only a short-term blip. If that is not the case, LOW may be able to accelerate its top and bottom-line expansion, which may be bullish for its stock.

Conclusion: Macro Shifts Appear Promising, But I Remain Cautious — A Hold

I think that Lowe's may appear to be an interesting opportunity for long-term investors who may seek to diversify into the retail industry with exposure to real estate markets. For multiple years now, the real estate landscape has been stressed, but recent progress highlighting an uptick in new home sales may be promising and supports a bullish stance for the company.

Nevertheless, it remains trading at elevated multiples, despite experiencing stagnation on both the top and bottom line. This highlights that the market may already be priced in for future growth, which would suggest upside may be limited in the near term. To that, there is a risk that improved consumer spending in real estate was just a one-off blip, which may suggest that investors could reprice the stock at a lower multiple if tailwinds do not materialize.

Given this, and a fairly valued stock, I think Lowe's Companies is a Hold. I think the stock may mirror bottom-line expansion, but I also don't believe it could significantly outperform the benchmark without a meaningful revenue growth catalyst. I forecast a $266 price target over the next 12 months, suggesting a 9% upside potential, but unlikely to outperform the broader market. 35 Wall Street analysts forecast a $282 price target, implying a roughly 18% upside possibility. This is a possibility, but I remain cautious until more data regarding real estate market activity appears.

data.title: Why Growth Investors Are Eyeing Broadcom As AI Market Expands
data.description:
I last wrote about Broadcom (NASDAQ: AVGO) on Sept. 11 when I upgraded it from a hold to a buy, despite its high valuation. The market has been reluctant to push the stock much higher recently, likely because some consider it overvalued. The stock has essentially flatlined since my last article on Broadcom. However, there are still reasons growth investors may want to purchase this stock despite trading at what some consider an elevated valuation.

The most significant reason investors may want to invest in Broadcom today is the potential for massive revenue growth acceleration from its artificial intelligence ("AI") business. Recently, Chief Executive Officer Hock Tan tied his pay incentives to the company's AI business, with the condition that the AI business achieve certain revenue in 2030. At the Goldman Sachs Communacopia + Technology Conference 2025 on Sept. 9, CEO Tan said:

As you know, I signed up for an extension of my contract to 2030. With this extension, of course, I get some incentives. One of that incentives that tied to it is tied to - so you guys know AI revenue for Broadcom, very simple. And I need to hit to achieve max on my incentive for 2030, five years from now, give you a sense, AI revenue of exceeding $120 billion, OK? Today, '25, our AI revenue is $20 billion. But that gives you a sense of our belief how strong the demand for compute is in this race towards AI, generative AI, super intelligence.

Suppose you plug those numbers ($20 billion in 2025 and $120 billion in 2030) into a compound annual growth rate ("CAGR") calculator. In that case, it results in a 43.1% CAGR over five years—absolutely explosive revenue growth from AI alone. Hock Tan has been the CEO of Broadcom since March 2006, following Avago Technologies' merger with Broadcom and the formation of the new Broadcom Inc. The company has displayed excellent execution during Hock Tan's reign. A bet that Hock Tan can guide Broadcom to $120 billion in AI revenue by 2030 is not a bad bet. It's within the realm of possibility, especially considering the growth of the AI marketplace.

He also noted at the conference that the company initially projected 60% revenue growth for fiscal year ("FY") 2026, but now expects that growth rate to accelerate beyond 60%. Typically, when revenue growth accelerates, momentum investors bid up the stock price. Broadcom's report date for fourth quarter 2025 earnings is on Dec. 11. If the company beats analysts' revenue estimates and raises 2026 guidance when it reports fourth-quarter earnings, it may spark a post-earnings rally in the stock—a good reason to invest in the near term.

AI Compute and networking

During the Goldman Sachs Communacopia + Technology Conference 2025, CEO Hock Tan explained he views the AI market in two distinct customer groups. The first group (the creators) consists of only a few significant players that include hyperscalers such as Alphabet (GOOGL)(GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and "super start-ups" or labs (like OpenAI, Anthropic) that are creating the Large Language Models (LLMs) and new platforms of the future. Hock Tan estimates that several players in the creator market spend up to $30 billion a year on AI infrastructure.

Hock Tan describes the creator group at the Goldman Sachs Conference:

These are the guys who are really making that investment in LLMs, which entail huge amount of R&D, particularly in respect to training, which is just - not just creating that algorithms to create those LLMs and make it work, but to also create the ability and spend on the ability to train huge amounts of data to improve on their journey towards super intelligence as we - for (want) of a better word.

The second group is a more fragmented group of AI users, or the enterprise market, consisting of thousands of regular companies, public cloud customers, and government/sovereign entities, who are primarily interested in using AI to improve their businesses and achieve "productivity gains." These users are rarely interested in doing much training. The AI user market is essentially the AI inference market. Hock Tan estimates the AI user market consists of around 10,000 customers today, each spending around $10 million a year, for a total of $100 billion.

CEO Tan also discussed the AI user market at the Goldman conference:

There's thousands and thousands of companies out there who are looking at AI as a very interesting tool to improve the way they run their business to basically achieve mostly productivity gains, which is truly - and trying to find use case for it and doubling most of them POCs (proof of concepts) right now on AI tools and trying to run AI and whether they get that ability through renting GPUs or buying some and running on-prem, these are that category. And that category of market are largely inference, truly inference. They talk about training. It's limited. Post training, perhaps, test time scaling, but it's all inference. It's looking for use case and trying to get a return on investment, mostly on productivity. And these guys are going to stay largely on merchant silicon, merchant GPU because they're not going to create XPUs, write software stacks to make it work and figure out all these things.

The creator group may have fewer potential customers, but it's still a sizeable market. Broadcom has little interest in marketing to the AI users market or enterprise customers who are primarily interested in using graphics processing units ("GPUs") manufactured by Nvidia (NVDA) or Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), rather than Broadcom's customized XPUs.

Although the AI chip gets all the hype, Broadcom's biggest advantage in AI infrastructure is its networking products. Not many companies have the resources to compete with Broadcom's networking knowledge, SerDes (Serializer/Deserializer) IP, and deep expertise. SerDes is the technology that moves data between chips at extremely high speeds. Broadcom has pioneered the development and integration of this high-speed IP into its ASICs, making it a key differentiating factor for building large AI clusters (XPUs/custom AI chips). Although many companies have entered the ASIC space over the years, competitors have had difficulty beating Broadcom in the AI infrastructure category because replicating its networking and connectivity technology is difficult.

The LLM Creator market is the only segment that truly pushes the limits of networking, a core Broadcom strength. CEO Hock Tan discussed the importance of networking at the Goldman Conference:

You are not able to do this generative AI training of this huge database to create this billion, billion parameters models with one single GPU or XPU, no matter how hard you try. You need to create a cluster of them. And the more complex your LLM becomes, the larger your clusters have to be. Then you face yourself a totally different problem. How do you create all this matrix multiplication across, say, 100,000 of the GPU simultaneously. And then you go to 1 million. That's even a bigger headache. That's one of the - that is, in fact, I consider the biggest technology challenge in computing on generative AI as you progress your models higher. And that comes in the other aspect, networking. How do you connect them? How do you have the bandwidth to connect them? How do you schedule the workloads, orchestrate it so that they can all run in parallel. This is more so as much software as the networking side, which is hardware. I think this is one of the biggest challenge towards progression, making massive progress on being able to create super intelligence. How do you get these huge workloads that you're supposed to run on these huge models and be able to train a huge amount of data on a 1 million GPU or XPU simultaneously and converge on a solution.

In other words, AMD and Nvidia, or one of the new players like Groq, Tenstorrent, Lightmatter, Mythic, Hailo, and SambaNova, could build the greatest individual AI chip in the world, and it would all be for naught if they're not networked together optimally. Since networking is Broadcom's bread and butter, with its IP in SerDes and high-performance Ethernet switches like Tomahawk and Jericho, it has a significant advantage over most companies. The only company that I can think of off the top of my head that has the networking chops to compete with Broadcom is Marvell (MRVL). So, despite press releases from some of its competitors about creating the latest and greatest super-duper chip, some will never be able to overcome Broadcom's networking moat. Customers who buy its hardware, networking, and software understand Broadcom's advantages, and it's unlikely these companies will switch to competitors easily in the near future.

Valuation

Broadcom's price-to-sales (P/S) ratio is 29.34, well above its three-, five-, seven-, and 10-year medians. Either the market overvalues the stock or expects revenue to increase rapidly or for its revenue to become more valuable (increasing margins).

If the stock begins trading at its three-year median today, its stock price would be $185.34, a 50% decline from its Oct. 28 market close of $372.97.

The following table compares Broadcom with its peers using its FY 2026 P/S to revenue growth (P/S/G) and trailing 12-month ("TTM") profitability metrics. Typically, in this comparison, the market considers the company with the highest P/S/G ratio as overvalued compared to those with the lowest P/S/G ratio.

Since companies with relatively lower revenue growth rates can skew the comparison, I'm excluding Qualcomm, ARM, and Intel from this comparison.

Among the relatively high-growth companies—Nvidia, Marvell, Broadcom, and AMD—Broadcom has the highest P/S/G, suggesting the market may overvalue it relative to its peers.

Since Broadcom lags only Nvidia in FCF margin, gross margin, and operating margin, and has a solid ROIC, the market likely considers its premium P/S/G justified. The market would likely consider Broadcom fairly valued to slightly undervalued in this comparison.

The following chart shows analysts' estimates that Broadcom's EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization) will grow from $41.85 billion in FY 2025 at a 30.35% CAGR to $71.16 billion in FY 2027.

The following table compares AMD's forward enterprise value to EBITDA, its two-year EBITDA CAGR, and its TTM EBITDA margin with those of its peers.

Company name Forward EV/EBITDA Two-year EBITDA CAGR TTM EBITDA margin Forward EV/EBITDA to two-year EBITDA growth

AMD 62.10 56.57% 18.74% 1.10
Broadcom 43.37 30.35% 54.61% 1.43
NVIDIA 38.07 30.13% 59.49% 1.26
Marvell 25.15 14.92% 24.33% 1.68
Intel 17.36 27.47% 21.22% 0.63
Qualcomm 12.03 0.64% 31.95% 18.79

I'm removing ARM from consideration in this comparison because it has the highest EV/EBITDA, but it doesn't have the highest EBITDA growth rates or margins. It's an anomaly in this comparison because it doesn't manufacture chips and only licenses the intellectual property, which distorts the EV/EBITDA comparison because it has lower operating costs than companies with manufacturing operations.

Generally, in this comparison, the market considers the company with the highest EV/EBITDA ratio to be overvalued compared to those with lower ratios. After excluding ARM, the market ranks AMD as the most overvalued, followed by Broadcom.

If we divide the EV/EBITDA by the EBITDA growth rate, the resulting figure tells us how much an investor is willing to pay for every dollar of a company's EBITDA growth. I will also exclude Qualcomm from the comparison because of its extremely low growth rate, which would make it another outlier.

After excluding ARM and Qualcomm, Marvell has the highest EV/EBITDA-to-growth, followed by Broadcom. The market would likely consider Broadcom overvalued compared to all companies in the comparison except Marvell.

The company's TTM price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is 95.81, well above the information technology sector median of 31.72, which the market would consider either a sign of overvaluation or that earnings will grow much faster in the future.

Broadcom's FY 2025 forward P/E to estimated earnings-per-share ("EPS") growth ("PEG") ratio is 1.43, calculated by dividing its FY 2025 forward P/E of 55.27 by analysts' estimated EPS growth of 38.56%. Since the stock has a PEG ratio between 1.0 and 2.0, growth investors may consider it fairly valued. Generally, growth investors will allow a stock's PEG to go above 2.0 before considering it overvalued. Suppose the stock traded at a PEG ratio of 2.0 today; the stock price would be $520.56, representing a 39.57% rise from its Oct. 28 price of $372.97.

If it sold at an FY 2026 PEG ratio of 2.0, its stock price would be $699.35, an 87.50% rise over its Oct. 28 closing price.

Its price-to-FCF ratio is 73.46, well above its three-, five-, seven-, and 10-year medians. Some investors may consider the stock overvalued. If it traded at its three-year median today, its stock price would be $162.72, a 56.37% decline from its Oct. 28 closing price.

The following reverse discounted cash flow uses a terminal growth rate of 3%, reflecting what I believe will be the U.S. market's long-term inflation rate. This reverse DCF uses a discount rate of 9%, which I base on AMD's weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 9.11%, reflecting an average or moderate risk level.

This reverse DCF analysis utilizes the following TTM FCF data from YCharts.

Reverse DCF

The fourth quarter of fiscal year (FY) 2025 reported TTM FCF

Terminal growth rate 3%
Discount Rate 9%
Years 1-10 growth rate 21.7%
Stock Price (October 28, 2025, closing price) $372.97
Terminal FCF value $187.568 billion
Discounted Terminal Value $1,320.510 billion
TTM FCF margin 41.60%

According to this reverse DCF, Broadcom needs to grow its FCF 21.7% annually over the next 10 years to justify its Oct. 28 closing price. The company would have a strong head start, as analysts forecast FCF growth of 49.56% in 2025, 44.68% in 2026, and 36.42% in 2027. Whether the company can sustain that growth beyond 2027 depends on whether it continues to benefit from AI industry growth, which is not guaranteed.

However, momentum investors likely don't care about the growth rate that the company can sustain over the next ten years. Momentum investors are looking at the FCF growth rates they believe the company can achieve in 2026 and 2027 to gauge whether to invest.

Risks

Broadcom's strategy of focusing on only a few "creators" in the AI market will result in significant customer concentration into a few large players, such as Google and Broadcom's new collaboration with OpenAI. If one of its customers reduces orders for any reason or if it loses a customer, revenue growth and profits could drop significantly. Investors would likely react negatively and sell off the stock.

Some of its hyperscaler customers are actively developing their own in-house chips (like Amazon's Trainium/Inferentia). Broadcom's role is to help hyperscalers build their own chips by supplying foundational IP (such as SerDes) and manufacturing expertise. However, as larger customers gain more experience in manufacturing AI chips, they may eventually cut out Broadcom entirely or move to a lower-cost partner.

Customer concentration within a few giant "creators" also carries the risk that they could gain negotiating leverage by threatening to move their business to competing infrastructure providers with lower prices or other advantages, such as Marvell. Broadcom may have to lower product prices to retain customers, potentially eroding gross margins.

Speaking of Marvell, its fiercest rival in the custom AI chip and high-speed networking market, has already secured major design wins in the past with hyperscalers like Amazon, Meta (META), and Microsoft. It's actively challenging Broadcom's market share in this lucrative space. While Broadcom has a solid moat in networking (SerDes, switches), it may not be a permanent technology edge. The technology industry has a long history of upstarts disrupting incumbents, and currently, Broadcom is an incumbent with what may eventually become legacy technology.

Broadcom also has other competitors that investors should keep an eye on, with the biggest being Nvidia, which has proprietary networking solutions (InfiniBand/NVLink, now Spectrum-X) and a comprehensive CUDA software platform, making it a challenging rival, even as Broadcom pushes its open Ethernet-based solutions, like Thor Ultra. The danger is that competitors may take enough market share to stunt Broadcom's growth or shrink its margins.

Broadcom remains a buy

Broadcom trades at an elevated valuation and, like many technology stocks, has risks that some conservative investors may want to avoid. Assuming upside from the current level implies an extremely aggressive valuation that may discourage value investors from buying it.

However, if you're a risk-tolerant investor willing to accept some risk in return for a potential high upside, Broadcom may be for you. Analysts estimate revenue to accelerate over the next year. Typically, the market bids up a company's stock price when its revenue growth accelerates. Its FY 2027 PEG ratio implies the stock has a potential 87.50% rise before reaching a PEG ratio of 2.0, the upper limit at which growth investors generally consider a stock overvalued.

I maintain my buy rating on Broadcom.

data.title: Meta Platforms: $73 Billion Lost In VR, The Ghost Of 2022 Has Returned To Haunt Shareholders
data.description:
In my previous article on Meta Platforms, Inc. (META), I warned about a potential drop since the valuation seemed a bit overstretched. Don’t get me wrong, the underlying business model has never been stronger as well as its competitive advantage, but the price always matters. Nothing is a buy regardless.

I have been buying Meta for a while, since 2022, and I have never sold a single share, but now I am waiting on the sidelines: in about three years, the stock has gone from $85 per share to almost $800. I know that fundamentals improved. However, the price per share doesn’t always go up and sometimes a drop is needed before getting higher: investors might want to realize some profits along the way.

Recently, the Q3 2025 results were released, and as a shareholder I was partially satisfied with the results. As I’ll show you, the core business keeps growing fast, but the VR business is raising some doubts: three years have passed and the cumulative losses are getting significant.

Growth continues, don't worry about taxes

Let’s start with the most important thing, in my opinion, the core business.

As you can see, Q3 2025 was a success in terms of growth but profitability slightly worsened. The Family of Apps segment experienced a 26% revenue growth, but the related operating income improved by “just” 16%. Operating costs for this quarter accelerated to sustain the data center's expansion. This led to a higher depreciation and third-party cloud spending.

Anyway, the results of these investments are evident in Meta’s core business.

The average price per ad went up by double digits in every region excluding Asia, and this means that Meta’s platforms are increasingly valued by advertisers. This is what really matters, and the fact that Meta's advertising business keeps growing fast is impressive. The billions invested in AI are creating more targeted advertisings, therefore more effective in generating actual sales.

Not just that, but people are spending more time on social media: compared to last year, 5% more on Facebook, 10% more on Threads, and 30% more on Instagram Reels. On top of that, daily active people passed the 3.50 billion threshold. That’s incredible, and consider that China doesn’t have access to these platforms. Basically, half of the world population uses one of Meta’s apps on a daily basis.

All these improvements couldn’t have happened without all the AI CapEx spending.

Finally, don’t get scared by the declining profits. They were influenced by a one-time noncash reduction in deferred tax assets following the implementation of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.

Without it, the tax rate would have been 14% and the company still expects to get tax savings over the next years. This quarter basically factored in all the expected effects from the transition to the updated U.S. tax law.

CapEx raises doubts

Okay, let’s now talk about the elephant in the room, the cumulative $73 billion losses of the VR segment.

As a shareholder, I always hope for a small recovery but VR continues to burn an increasing amount of cash. For the next quarter, further headwinds are expected since there isn’t a new headset in the market.

We started from $2 billion per quarter, and now we are approaching $5 billion as CapEx keeps growing.

YTD, the company registered a CapEx of $50.07 billion and there is still a quarter left: it is more than double what the company spent in 2024. Anyway, that is not what is worrying investors.

The company announced that 2026 CapEx will be notably larger than 2025 but it didn’t provide more details. We don’t know what they mean by notably larger; it might be $60 billion, $80 billion, or even $100 billion. Meta generated LTM cash from operations of $107 billion, so these kinds of figures are high even for one of the best companies in the world.

I can’t have any certainty, but I guess that 2026 CapEx will be close to $100 billion. Meta is about to raise $30 billion in bonds to fund the AI spending, and I don’t think they are doing that to increase the CapEx just by $5 billion-$10 billion.

With that said, a question arises: why is the market is so tough with Meta? Microsoft Corporation (MSFT), Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) and Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) (GOOGL) are increasing AI spending as well, but their price per share is heading toward a new all-time high. Well, I think there are multiple reasons for this.

Firstly, investing in Meta means investing in CEO Mark Zuckerberg’s vision, something that doesn’t happen with other big tech companies. Zuckerberg controls 58% of voting rights, so he has a huge power in implementing his ideas. This is both a positive and a negative aspect. His intuition about Instagram and WhatsApp was definitely correct, but we can’t know how far he will go with the VR segment. The losses are getting significant and we don’t see any sign of improvement. By doubling CapEx next year, I suppose the quarterly losses might even be higher than $5 billion; that’s a big amount of money even for Meta.

But what exactly is Mark Zuckerberg’s vision? He provided useful insights during the last conference call:

So my view on this is that rather than continuing to be constrained on CapEx and feeling in the core business like we have significant investments that we could make that we're not able to make that would be profitable. But the right thing to do is to try to accelerate this to make sure that we have the compute that we need, both for the AI research and new things that we're doing, and to try to get to a different state on our compute stance on the core business. So that's kind of how I'm thinking about that overall.

I think we can sum it up as follows: I don’t care what the market thinks, I am going to invest whatever CapEx we need to exploit this huge opportunity. Even if this means investing a huge part of the cash from operations and getting into debt. And this is exactly what is happening.

Before getting into the VR segment, Meta had a net debt of -$50 billion. Therefore, it held much more cash than debt. Now, the net debt is $6.46 billion and I don’t think this figure includes the ongoing bond issuance. Nothing to worry about in terms of debt sustainability, but I think it is something to look at. It shows that the company is willing to do whatever it can to lead the AI industry, even worsening its financial position.

Mark Zuckerberg's approach is quite extreme, that is why investors are considering Meta as a riskier investment. However, let’s not get confused about where all this money will be invested. As Zuckerberg stated, most of the CapEx will be allocated to the core business, therefore Family of Apps, not VR.

The fact that Family of Apps' profitability declined is not helping either, because investors are wondering if this huge CapEx is really worth it. And Mark Zuckerberg didn’t provide some clarity about it.

I think it's too early to really understand what the margins are going to be for the new products that we build. I mean, I think certainly, every -- each product has somewhat different characteristics. And I think we'll kind of understand how that goes over time. I mean, my general goal is to build a business that maximizes value for the people who use our products and maximizes profitability, not margin. So I think we'll kind of just try to build the best things that we can and try to deliver the most value that we can for most people.

So, it is too early to estimate the profitability improvements out of the billions invested. In terms of revenue growth it is pretty visible though.

Conclusion

Among the biggest tech companies, I believe Meta is the one that presents the most grey areas. The company is willing to invest every dollar to exploit the current opportunities, and I appreciate that. On the other hand, I see a VR segment that burns about $18 billion- $20 billion each year, and I honestly wonder if it is really worth it. When I first invested in Meta, the net debt was -$50 billion, now $6 billion. Still peanuts for Meta, but the cumulative losses are starting to hurt.

The core business is improving a lot in terms of revenue growth, but in terms of profitability, it is struggling a bit. Compared to Alphabet, Microsoft or Amazon, we can’t associate the AI spending with increasing operating profit from the Cloud business, and this makes it harder to understand how profitable these investments actually are.

Anyway, I still firmly believe in this company and it remains one of my biggest holdings. I think we can try to understand where all these investments are going up to a certain point, then we can only trust the management. If they believe that lots of great opportunities are ahead, I am not against going all-in: building the proper infrastructure earlier can really make a difference.

Furthermore, an aspect that often tends to be overlooked is that Meta can rely on 3.54 billion daily active users. Basically, the company can monetize in millions of ways all the investments it is making, something that other companies can do only to some extent. Its competitive advantage based on the network effect is something that nobody was able to replicate.

I still believe Meta is a great business, and I don’t plan to sell any shares in the foreseeable future. Anyway, even though it dropped quite a bit recently, I am waiting for lower levels to buy some shares.

At the current price and with a RRR of 12%, the stock is pricing in a 20.50% growth over the next 10 years. This is a feasible assumption, but definitely not conservative.

I would rather wait $600 or even $550 before jumping back in, partly because Meta already has a big weight in my portfolio. For now, I’ll just watch how the situation evolves, and I don’t rule out a further drop.

We are definitely not in the same situation as in 2022, but investors might make this wrong association. After all, VR losses are growing as well as Capex. As they see the stock falling by double digits, they might lose focus and believe once again that Meta is burning all the money “because of the Metaverse”. I hope you got it that this is not the case, and most of the money invested is for Family of Apps, which is why revenue grew over 20% year-over-year.

After years of strong stock price rises, we might witness a period where Meta is very cheap again. I look forward to catching those opportunities.

data.title: Antero Midstream: Free Cash Flow Nearly Doubles From The Last Fiscal Year Comparison
data.description:
Ever since the oil and gas industry was seen as a far lower growth industry than it was the case over a decade ago, there has been an unparalleled increase in attention paid to free cash flow. Antero Midstream Corporation (AM) just mentioned that free cash flow took a roughly 94% leap over the same quarter in the previous fiscal year. That is the kind of leap that keeps future stock price appreciation as a reasonable goal from the current price.

A lot of LNG export capacity continues to come online. There is also a focus on datacenter growth as another potentially large increase in the use of natural gas. All of this could mean that the North American natural gas market could well join the much stronger world pricing market. Since the stock prices of the midstream industry tend to follow the lead of upstream stock prices, it could well mean that there is more appreciation potential in the future for this stock.

The parent company, Antero Resources (AR), placed a "spot rig" on dry gas acreage that had not been drilled for some time. That is an extremely visible vote for a very favorable commodity price future that many believe the industry faces.

It is possible that capital requirements for Antero Midstream could increase in the future if Antero Resources elects to take advantage of the situation by growing production. If that is the case, the growth of the Midstream Business would mean more free cash flow in the future that could be distributed to shareholders or used in stock repurchases.

It was also mentioned that the company purchased treasury shares during the quarter. This is likewise a potential vote for the opinion that the stock is undervalued.

Earnings And Free Cash Flow After Dividends

Earnings also grew in the teens in the comparison shown below:

Note that the dramatic growth in free cash flow for this management was after dividends. Free cash flow before dividends also grew at a nice pace. But nothing close to the headline that management put out.

The start of a stock purchase plan likely signals that there is a cushion developing that may later allow for a dividend increase. This dividend has not been increased in several years. But the growth in free cash flow shown above, combined with management's tendency to find good used deals on equipment (usually through bolt-on acquisitions), could mean that a dividend increase may finally be a possibility within the medium-term future.

Doing things this way means that if, for some reason, there is a cash flow decline, the dividend is very defensible in that the stock repurchase program can be eliminated first. This would also happen if capital needs increased.

Debt

The earnings press release also mentioned a debt upgrade that can lead to lower debt costs in the future.

The debt rating was upgraded at Moody's. With the current debt ratio among the lowest in the midstream industry, there could be more debt rating upgrades. The main customer, Antero Resources (AR) has been upgraded to investment grade.

That gives some room for more investment grades here. Both managements of Antero Resources and Antero Midstream have long explained that the highest debt rating that Antero Midstream can attain is whatever the major customer (Antero Resources) has for a debt rating.

Even though the debt rating is below investment grade, it is likely high enough to allow this company to use the debt market for whatever debt needs it has at a reasonable cost. While the rating is considerable somewhat speculative, it is at the higher end of the speculative range.

Map Of Operations

Antero Midstream has long grown a bit faster than the parent company. This is possible because the midstream operations never serviced the entire Antero Resources acreage.

The rig drilling on the dry gas acreage is using the capacity acquired a couple of years back, as shown above. There is still more room for growth using the available capacity.

Antero Resources management has long admitted to drilling rich gas acreage because it was more profitable to drill. But now things could be changing to the extent that the dry gas acreage could again be something to consider.

Antero Resources has also been purchasing subpar-sized positions that are right next to larger company positions. Some of these can be serviced in the future by Antero Midstream as well.

Summary

Midstream stocks often follow the upstream stocks, even though the midstream business itself is a very different business.

But despite the fact that this stock has appreciated considerably since 2021, there is likely still more appreciation potential as long as the natural gas pricing recovery continues.

The market has long not paid attention to the fact that this business is very steady and without a lot of upstream risks. There are take-or-pay provisions that assure a minimum.

Plus, this business does not service all of the Antero Resources business. It never has. Now, some acquisitions, like the capacity that serviced the dry gas acreage, have likely increased the percentage of the business serviced by Antero Midstream.

There is also the possibility that, as the midstream business grows, there could be more value-added businesses to consider. That could potentially make this company more of a "one-stop shop" for those customers where that is important.

On the other hand, this is one of the more richly priced midstream companies that I follow. Since there is a fear of a recession or worse due to the political uncertainty that exists. I would probably consider this a hold right now, even though I suspect there is still more long-term capital appreciation potential as long as natural gas prices continue to rise (long-term).

This company has a lot going for it. As such, I like everything but the stock price and the current market environment, that is caused by the political uncertainty. I intend to upgrade back to a buy as soon as this uncertainty that is causing the industry to "hunker down" goes away.

Risks

With a hold rating, there are both risks to the upside and to the downside to consider for such a decision.

On the downside, the threat of tariffs and trade wars, combined with still more political uncertainty, may bring about a recession or worse if this is not replaced by something permanent and constructive.

On the upside, a quick resolution of the current situation that would allow the economy to return to the growth mode that marked 2024 would be the upside risk.

The company also has a new CEO. While the previous CEO is still around, there is a transition underway that may also cause the stock price to wobble at times. The new CEO needs to establish his own record that is comparable to what was happening before he took the job.

Mutual Fund performance changes over time and currently may be significantly lower than stated above. Performance is updated and published monthly. Current month-end performance can be obtained at dodgeandcox.com or by calling 800-621-3979.

Market Commentary

Emerging market equities continued their strong performance during the third quarter. While U.S. stocks have recovered after stumbling earlier in the year, emerging market stocks have provided even higher absolute returns, as well as diversification benefits relative to other asset classes. China was particularly notable, as the MSCI China Index returned over 40% year to date. Its equity markets continued to benefit from domestic policy support and enthusiasm for technological breakthroughs in artificial intelligence (AI). South Korea has also been a market standout, benefiting from its key role in AI supply chains and improved political stability. Meanwhile, Latin American stocks continued to bounce back from 2024 with strong third quarter returns. Overall, the MSCI Emerging Markets had a total return of 10.6% for the third quarter and 27.5% year to date.

While emerging market valuations have risen to 14.0 times forward earnings, their valuation relative to the U.S. market has remained consistently compelling.2 The relative value of emerging market stocks compared to U.S. stocks is at one of the lowest levels over the past 20 years. Furthermore, spreads are extremely wide among emerging market equities, as measured by dispersions in sector and regional valuations. This presents attractive opportunities for price-disciplined investors.

Portfolio Strategy

As noted, China has been a stellar performer. Alibaba (BABA), China’s largest ecommerce and cloud computing platform, has been the Fund’s largest contributor to relative performance in 2025.3 However, the strength in the Fund’s Chinese holdings returns extends beyond internet-related names. Given the broad range of opportunity, we continue to diversify the Fund’s Greater China exposure.4 We established a position in DiDi Global (OTCPK:DIDIY), China’s dominant ride-sharing platform, during the second quarter, and the stock is up 48% as our thesis of profitability inflection materialized. In the third quarter, we initiated a position in Sungrow Power Supply, a leading global supplier of solar power systems and energy storage solutions. We also added to the Fund’s position in Greentown Service Group (OTCPK:GRTNF), a property management company with an attractive valuation, focused management team, and improved guidance for future profitability.

In terms of sectors, Energy and Industrials were the top two contributors to performance in the third quarter. In Energy, National Energy Services Reunited (NESR), an oilfield services company operating in MENA and Asia-Pacific returned over 70%, adding 120 basis points of relative value versus the Index. The stock detracted from results during the first half of the year, but we added to the Fund’s position because our knowledge of the company’s fundamentals gave us long-term confidence. Our willingness to add to positions in times of short-term volatility and uncertainty is a hallmark of our strategy. The Fund’s outperformance in the Industrials sector was led by positions in United Integrated Services, a Taiwanese engineering and construction services company, and Contemporary Amperex Technology (OTC:CTATF)[CATL], a Chinese lithium battery manufacturer.

Given the heightened unpredictability of current macroeconomic and geopolitical events, we expect continuing short-term volatility due to the nature of the emerging market landscape. Risks to the global economic and political order remain, including unknown effects of global tariff wars, increasing geopolitical risk in the Middle East, and volatile energy and commodity prices. Nevertheless, we continue to adhere to our disciplined investment approach and maintain our long-term investment horizon. Thank you for your continued confidence in Dodge & Cox.

Third Quarter

Key contributors to relative results included the Fund’s:

  • Energy holdings—notably National Energy Services Reunited;
  • Industrials holdings, including United Integrated Services, CATL, and DiDi Global;

  • Taiwanese dollar and Chinese renminbi currency hedges; and
